Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, West Nile Virus)
Schizophrenia (in the context of an autoimmune disorder with CNS involvement)
Schizophrenia (for isolated psychosis without other systemic causes)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C, which can present with similar symptoms)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including psychosis, autoimmune hemolysis, pericarditis, and in some cases, may lead to pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily known for its joint manifestations, RA can also cause pericarditis, autoimmune hemolysis, and in rare cases, systemic symptoms including psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reason: This disease combines features of multiple autoimmune diseases, including SLE and rheumatoid arthritis, potentially leading to psychosis, pericarditis, and autoimmune hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily affecting exocrine glands, Sjögren's can have systemic manifestations, including pericarditis and in rare cases, hemolytic anemia. Neurological involvement can sometimes present as psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reason: Although known for its distinctive skin and muscle symptoms, dermatomyositis can also cause pericarditis and has been associated with autoimmune-mediated phenomena.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: Sarcoidosis can affect various organs including skin (leading to hyperkeratosis), heart (causing pericardial effusions), and nervous system (potentially leading to psychiatric symptoms). It can also cause autoimmune hemolysis in rare cases.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.reason: Certain viral infections can trigger acute pericarditis and pericardial effusion. Autoimmune hemolysis could also be secondary to viral infection. Psychosis might not be directly related but can occur in severe systemic infections.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: Lymphoma can cause pericardial effusion and in advanced stages or certain subtypes, can lead to autoimmune hemolysis. Psychosis would be less directly related but can occur in the context of systemic illness.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reason: In advanced stages, HIV can lead to a myriad of symptoms including psychosis (due to opportunistic infections or directly by the virus), autoimmune hemolysis, and less commonly, pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus-Systemic
diagnoses.reason: This entry reaffirms Systemic Lupus Erythematosus due to its significance and wide spectrum of symptoms that match the query, including psychosis, pericarditis, autoimmune hemolysis, and more.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (for psychosis, given no direct relation, this reflects a possible comorbid condition)
Vitamin A deficiency (related to follicular hyperkeratosis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including leukopenia, psoriasiform rash, and serositis (which may lead to pericardial effusion and acute pericarditis). Discoid lupus erythematosus, a subset of SLE, may lead to atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: Psoriatic arthritis can present with psoriasiform rash and can occasionally cause cardiac manifestations. It may also lead to skin lesions that heal with atrophic scars.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: In severe cases, can cause pericardial effusions and acute pericarditis in addition to rheumatoid nodules that might leave atrophic scarring upon involution. Leukopenia can occur secondary to the disease or as a side effect of drugs used in treatment.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.reason: Scleroderma often involves atrophic scarring and can have cardiac involvement including pericarditis. It can also lead to skin manifestations that resemble psoriasis and hematological abnormalities, including leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reason: This condition can present with features of several connective tissue diseases, including psoriasiform rash, leukopenia, and potentially atrophic scars due to skin involvement. Cardiac complications can include pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reason: While primarily known for muscle weakness and skin changes, dermatomyositis can sometimes cause atrophic scarring, pericardial effusion, or acute pericarditis. Leukopenia and skin rashes resembling psoriasis may also occur.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reason: Certain drugs can induce a lupus-like syndrome, which might include leukopenia, pericardial effusion, and a rash resembling psoriasis. Patients may also develop atrophic scarring similar to those seen in SLE.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Pericarditis
diagnoses.reason: While more specific to pericarditis, infectious etiologies can sometimes present with broader systemic symptoms including rashes and leukopenia, depending on the infection. Association with atrophic scarring is less direct.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: Sarcoidosis can affect multiple organ systems, including the skin (leading to atrophic scarring), heart (pericardial effusion and pericarditis), and can sometimes cause leukopenia. Skin involvement may mimic psoriasis.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Myocarditis
diagnoses.reason: While primary involvement is the heart, autoimmune myocarditis could theoretically be linked with systemic autoimmune responses, including skin manifestations, atrophic scars, and blood dyscrasias like leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that affects white blood cells. It's characterized by the overproduction of immature lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell.

diagnoses.name: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)
diagnoses.description: Another type of cancer that starts in the cells that become white blood cells (other than lymphocytes), red blood cells, or platelet-producing cells.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts from white blood cells (lymphocytes) in the bone marrow. CLL primarily affects older adults and may cause lymphadenopathy and immunosuppression.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: A disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding, resulting from unusually low levels of platelets — the cells that help blood clot.

diagnoses.name: Hemophilia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your blood doesn't clot normally because it lacks sufficient blood-clotting proteins (clotting factors). This can cause easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder caused by low levels of clotting protein in the blood. It affects your blood's ability to clot.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that causes recurrent episodes of severe swelling. The most common areas of the body to develop swelling are the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by periods of illness, called flares, and periods of wellness, or remission.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in your lymphatic system, the disease-fighting network spread throughout your body. In non-Hodgkin lymphoma, tumors develop from lymphocytes.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. Sjögren's syndrome often accompanies other immune system disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

diagnoses: Dental Caries or other sources of Dental and Oral pain

diagnoses.rationale: Connective tissue disorder that can cause hypermobility, along with various other systemic manifestations that might indirectly contribute to the other symptoms.
Characterized by extreme fatigue that worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. It can also manifest with sleep abnormalities, pain, and sensory sensitivities.
Known for causing widespread body pain, fatigue, sleep disturbances, and increased sensitivity to physical stimuli. People with fibromyalgia may also experience difficulty focusing.
Autonomic dysregulation can lead to widespread symptoms including fatigue, sleep disturbances, and hypermobility in some cases.
Can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms including problems with vision, sleep disturbances, and sensitivity to stimuli.
An autoimmune disease that can cause dryness that could potentially contribute to difficulty focusing vision and outer ear problems like Otitis Externa due to dry skin.

A tick-borne illness that can lead to a variety of symptoms including sleep disturbances, joint issues (potentially leading to hypermobility if affecting connective tissue), and neurocognitive effects including focus issues.
Anxiety can lead to hyperarousal which might manifest as difficulty sleeping (insomnia), difficulty concentrating, and a heightened state of physical sensitivity.
Depression can significantly impact sleep patterns (leading to insomnia) and concentration, and can heighten bodily discomfort.
People with autism may experience sensory sensitivities, sleep disturbances, and challenges with attention and hypermobility in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Hypermobility is a common feature.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry mouth and dry eyes. It can lead to oral pain and can affect the sense of taste.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. It can lead to mouth sores, leading to oral pain, and can affect other areas leading to mood lability.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs. It can cause mood lability and dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that causes features of several connective tissue diseases, such as Lupus, Scleroderma, and Polymyositis, including hypermobility, oral pain, and potentially lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It can indirectly lead to mood lability and dysgeusia due to associated conditions.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease of blood vessels that can cause a wide array of symptoms, including pain in the face and mouth, and can affect the lymph nodes causing lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including dysgeusia and potentially impact oral health or lead to lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can cause various neurological and psychiatric disorders, which might manifest as mood lability, and oral pain or dysgeusia due to the effect on the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: The virus attacks the immune system, and while it progresses, it can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including lymphadenitis, dysgeusia, and oral pain due to opportunistic infections.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation and infection of the stomach and intestines that causes vomiting and diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease
diagnoses.description: Infection of the female reproductive organs, often related to endometriosis and may cause chronic pain.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of adrenal gland tissue causing episodes of high blood pressure, headaches, sweating, and rapid heartbeat that may explain blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue, pain, and lymphadenitis without an underlying medical condition.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs, including potential for endometriosis exacerbation.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia burgdorferi bacterium. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including swelling of lymph nodes and chronic pain.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system) where the immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A painful disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of your uterus — the endometrium — grows outside your uterus.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental health disorders characterized by significant feelings of anxiety and fear, which may contribute to physical symptoms like blood pressure lability and chronic pain.

diagnoses: Otitis Media with Effusion in Immunodeficiency
Blepharospasm as part of Neurological Syndromes
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a range of neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances such as scotomas and scintillations, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, leading to symptoms such as numbness and paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes, leading to numbness, tingling, and pain.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause a temporary loss of vision, often in one eye, and is often associated with multiple sclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA occurs when blood flow to part of the brain stops for a short period of time, causing temporary symptoms similar to a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause a variety of neurological symptoms depending on its location.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disorder that causes muscle weakness and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can lead to neurological problems, including numbness, tingling, and problems with vision.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Viral Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea or vomiting, and sometimes fever.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, and your body doesn't have enough water and other fluids to carry out its normal functions.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, resulting in a range of symptoms including weakness and numbness, often with paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, causing fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Ketoacidosis
diagnoses.description: A serious diabetes complication where the body produces excess blood acids (ketones), characterized by symptoms such as nausea and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, leading to symptoms like fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
diagnoses.description: Exposure to carbon monoxide gas, which can cause a range of symptoms including headache, weakness, dizziness, nausea or vomiting, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes surrounding your brain and spinal cord, usually caused by an infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition in which poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms may include paralysis, speech disturbances, and loss of muscle movement, along with headache and possibly altered consciousness.

diagnoses: Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA, formerly Churg-Strauss Syndrome)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Hepatitis B or C associated cryoglobulinemia
